quizzes.title: History Quiz: Time and Germany
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, defeat, world. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which organization did the Allies create in 1945 in order to maintain peace after World War II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The United Nations

questions.question: This significant battle on the WW II  Eastern front is largely regarded as the largest armed conflict of all time.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The battle of Kursk

questions.question: What was the aim of The Molotov-Ribbentrop pact, signed on 23 August 1939 between Germany and the Soviet Union?

options.text: Division of the spheres of interest
A united attack against Great Britain

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Division of the spheres of interest

questions.question: What was the name of the ancient Greek wrestling school, which was later used  for delivering lectures and conducting intellectual conversations?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: palaestra

questions.question: In the ancient Greek society, these women were high-class entertainers, much like the Japanese geisha.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: hetaerae

questions.question: Who are the two ancient Greek architects who designed the Parthenon, a temple regarded as one of the worlds greatest cultural monuments.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Iktinos and Kallikrates

questions.question: Until which event did the US remain neutral in the Second World War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Pearl Harbor attack

questions.question: Where did the official Japanese surrender on 2nd September 1945 take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: USS Missouri

questions.question: What 1945 conference considered the final plans for the defeat of Germany and postwar Europe?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yalta Conference

questions.question: This ancient Greek construction, regarded as one the Seven Wonders of the World, was carved by the famed classical sculptor Phidias.

options.text: The Statue of Zeus at Olympia
The Mausoleum of Maussollos at Halicarnassus

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Statue of Zeus at Olympia

questions.question: What ancient Greek vessel was used to mix wine and water?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: krater

questions.question: Arbeit macht frei was a popular German slogan during World War II, placed mainly on the entrances of which of these?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: German concentration camps

questions.question: This ancient Greek wrote The Histories, a document considered the first work of history in Western literature.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Herodotus

questions.question: What happened on D-day, 6th June,1944?

options.text: The end of World War II was announced.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Operation Overlord started.

questions.question: This ancient Greek, despite having a speech impediment, was one of the greatest orators in his time.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Demosthenes

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Invention and Mount Everest
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, actor, deadliest. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The invention of the internal combustion engine greatly increased the demand for which natural resource?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Petroleum

questions.question: May 10, 1996 is considered the single deadliest day in the history of Mount Everest. Eight people lost their lives, including famed Everest mountain guides Rob Hall and Scott Fischer. Outside Magazine had contracted a writer to be a part of Rob Halls accent of Mount Everest. What writer turned his experience on Mount Everest into the non-fiction bestseller Into Thin Air?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jon Krakauer

questions.question: This world famous haute couture designer moved to Miami when he was selected as the costume designer for Miami Vice. What designer was gunned down outside his house by spree killer Andrew Cunanan?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Versace

questions.question: Many in Hollywood were nervous when this lady was arraigned on charges of pandering and tax evasion on August 9, 1993. Who was known as the Hollywood Madam or Madam to the Stars?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Heidi Fleiss

questions.question: This ancient Greek playwright was the earliest of the three classical Greek tragedians, the other two being Sophocles and Euripides.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aeschylus

questions.question: On June 17, 1994 actor and football legend O. J. Simpson, instead of turning himself into the authorities to be charged for the murder of his wife Nicole and her friend Ron Goldman, led the police on a slow speed chase on Interstate 405. O. J. Simpson was a passenger in the white Ford Bronco. Who drove the white Bronco?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Al Cowlings

questions.question: This ancient Greek philosopher, a teacher of  Aristotle, was the founder of the Academy in Athens.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Plato

questions.question: This invention was first used in 1969 at UCLA as a means of communication between engineers and scientists associated with academics or government. It was not available for public use until the 1990’s.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Internet

questions.question: Which of these movies won all five of the top categories: Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Director and Best Screenplay?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Silence of the Lambs

questions.question: Always a bridesmaid and never a bride. No more!  What daytime soap actress won an Emmy
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Susan Lucci

questions.question: This invention by Karl Benz in 1886 revolutionized the world of transportation and soon became the main means of transport globally.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Automobile

questions.question: In 1908, this city became the first in the United States to institute chlorination of its water. Prior to this the death rate due to water born diseases, such as typhoid fever and cholera, were extremely high.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jersey City, New Jersey

questions.question: Which structure served as a market place in an acnient Greek polis or city-state?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: agora

questions.question: The 1998 film, Theres Something About Mary, helped make this model turned actress one of the highest paid actresses in Hollywood. Who said Is that ...is that hair gel?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cameron Diaz

questions.question: When did telephone companies first begin establishing trial networks, that use fibre instead of copper cables to carry live telephone traffic?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: in 1977

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Battle and Use
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, radiation. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Tin soldiers and Nixon coming
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kent State University

questions.question: Which Academy Award winning American actor who died in 2003 played Ed Norton on The Honeymooners?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Art Carney

questions.question: What battle of 1781 resulted in a decisive victory of the American army against Great Britain and caused the British government to negotiate an end of the American Revolutionary War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of Yorktown

questions.question: The first use of air conditioning for personnel comfort was in 1902, in which New York City building?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York Stock Exchange

questions.question: In 1955, Borax III became the first nuclear power plant to utilize nuclear fission to supply an entire town with electricity. Which town was that?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Arco, Idaho

questions.question: During the Wars of Scottish Independence, this 1314 battle resulted in a decisive Scottish victory over England.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of Bannockburn

questions.question: This western character actor was in the role of Deputy Jake in Support Your Local Sheriff with James Garner. Before his death on 20 October 2003, he often played the villain in westerns and openly said it was because of his lazy eye.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jack Elam

questions.question: This sassy matronly housekeeper on Give Me A Break! was 54 when she died in 2003.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nell Carter

questions.question: In 1895, this German physicist invented the use of electromagnetic radiation to take images of bones and organs inside the human body, which later led to the invention of the X-Ray Machine.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen

questions.question: It began on July 1st, 1916, and is considered by many, the most devastating battle of World War I, resulting in more than one million casualties.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of the Somme

questions.question: This flamboyantly-dressed announcer on The Price Is Right died on October 27th, 2003 in Los Angeles.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rod Roddy

questions.question: Actor Lee Marvin who starred in the Death Wish movies succumbed to cancer in 2003.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: The most famous battle of the Hundred Years War between England and France resulted in a massive French army being defeated by a much smaller English army, led by King Henry V. Where did this battle take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Agincourt

questions.question: Earl Hindman, who passed away in 2003, was the man behind the fence in the American sitcom Home Improvement.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What city-state was the primary rival of Athens during the Peloponnesian war of 431 BC?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sparta

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Battle and End
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, leader, chords. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which top Nazi Leader, considered a possible successor of Hitler, chief of the Reich Main Security Office, and Reich governor of Bohemia and Moravia, was killed during Operation Anthropoid?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Reinhard Heydrich

questions.question: On 18 February 1943, Joseph Goebbels gave a speech, aiming to persuade the Germans not to give up Nazi idealism. The speech was delivered in front of which building, located near Potzdamer Platz?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Berlin Sportpalast

questions.question: It was just the musical chords of E and F played alternately back and forth but even to this day
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jaws

questions.question: Which countries were Israels enemies during the 1967 Arab-Israeli War, also known as the Six-Day War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Egypt, Syria, Jordan

questions.question: This organization, often referred to as a predecessor of the European Union, was founded after WW II to prevent the outbreak of such conflicts.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: European Coal and Steel Community

questions.question: During Operation Barbarossa, which began on June 22, 1941, the Red Army was found unprepared for a possible attack for what reason?

options.text: The aviation units were not dispersed and ready for a battle
There was a disorganization in the armor units
Stalin didnt believe that the Third Reich was going to attack only two years after signing the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What was the name of the bomb dropped over Nagasaki during WW II?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fat Man

questions.question: Winston Churchill made the following statement about the battle that occurred between October 23 and November 3, 1942: Now this is not the end, it is not even the beginning of the end. But it is, perhaps, the end of the beginning. Name the battle.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Second Battle of El Alamein

questions.question: Which of the following is not associated with the Battle of Gettysburg, the bloodiest battle of the American Civil War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bloody Lane

questions.question: Which battle of the Korean War in started on September 15, 1950 when United States marines launched a massive attack on a South Korean port?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of Inchon

questions.question: The British colony of Hong Kong was finally defeated by Japanese Forces in December, 1941 on Christmas day. The locals called that day by what name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Black Christmas

questions.question: The First Indochina War came to a dramatic and unexpected end when over 7,000 French soldiers were killed at which small Vietnamese village?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dien Bien Phu

questions.question: Rosie the Riveter was a character that represented all the women joining the workforce during World War II, when the factories were empty and needed staff. The picture of Rosie could be seen on many posters and stamps all of which had what slogan?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: We can do it!

questions.question: This major battle that the Germans failed during WW II became the largest armored engagement of all time, and included the most costly single day of aerial warfare in history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The battle of Kursk

questions.question: The Charge of the Light Brigade, which remained in history as a rather incompetent and unsuccessful cavalry charge, led by Lord Cardigan, occurred during which military conflict?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Crimean War

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Team and Year
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, college, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The town of Hastings, where the Battle of Hastings took place, is located in which county?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: East Sussex

questions.question: The first hot air balloon was created in 1783.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Who conquered England as a result of the Battle of Hastings?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Normans

questions.question: The movie No Country for Old Men based on the novel by Cormac McCarthy was on many list of 10 Best Films of the Year and won Best Picture from the National Board of Review and the Critics Choice Awards.  Who directed No Country for Old Men?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Coen Brothers

questions.question: Together at last! Late Show with David Letterman won the # 1 spot in The 10 Best TV Ads.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oprah Winfrey

questions.question: If you cant do the time, dont commit the crime. Which of the following celebrities spent the LEAST amount of time in jail in 2007?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nicole Richie

questions.question: What war began in 1914?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: World War I

questions.question: When was the first rollercoaster built?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1884

questions.question: The Cold war, which began in 1947 was a consequence of World War II. Who were the leaders of the two superpowers (The USA and the Soviet Union) at the beginning of the Cold War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Truman and Stalin

questions.question: Time Magazine made a list of The Ten Best Buzzwords of 2007. The #1 Buzzword was a noun meaning an older woman who romantically pursues younger men.  What was Time Magazines # 1 Buzzword in 2007?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cougar

questions.question: What gentleman made the cover of Details Magazine and was ranked # 7 as a Good Father in Details Magazines 50 Most Influential Men Under 45?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kevin Federline

questions.question: People Magazine named a 2007 Star of the Year. This star is the new face of Versace, plays around with a Grand-Am race car and became the father of two. Who is this Prince Charming?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Patrick Dempsey

questions.question: What author broke the record for book sales when the last book in her famous series sold 15 million copies in 24 hours?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: J. K. Rowling

questions.question: In college football, 2007 may well be remembered as the year of the upset. On October 13, November 23, 24 and December 1st both the # 1and # 2 teams in the US suffered upsets and the 2007 regular season ended with Pitts shocking  win over West Virginia. But it was the defeat of Michigan, the fifth ranked team in the nation, by a 1-AA team that has been touted by many as the greatest upset in college football history. What team became the first 1-AA team to beat a ranked 1- A team?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Appalachian State University

questions.question: Who was Time Magazines Person of the Year for 2007?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vladimir Putin

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Shuttle and U.s.
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, john. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: How did former FBI anti-terrorist squad leader John ONeill die on 9/11?

options.text: He was attending a meeting in the portion of  the Pentagon that was struck by one of the hijacked planes.
He was in the midst of new duties as head of security at the World Trade Center.
He was helping firemen rescue people trapped on the top floors of the South Tower when it collapsed.
He was a passenger on the plane that crashed in Pennsylvania.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was in the midst of new duties as head of security at the World Trade Center.

questions.question: The events of 9/11 occurred on the Tuesday after Labor Day.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Space Shuttles are transported to the launch pad on this slow-moving 6,000,000 pound (approx. 2,725,000 kg) vehicle.  Fully loaded, it moves at a rate of 1 mph.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Shuttle Crawler Transporter

questions.question: William the Conqueror was crowned King William I in Westminster Abbey, about two months after the Battle of Hastings.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The Shuttle consisted of 2.5 million parts, including more than 1,000 plumbing valves, 1,400 circuit breakers and 230 miles of wire. The most complex job of building the Shuttle went to this company in Southern California.  They had to design and assemble the orbiter itself.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rockwell International

questions.question: Which Anglo-Saxon King of England died at the Battle of Hastings?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Harold II

questions.question: How many minutes did President Bush remain seated, reading My Pet Goat in a 3rd-grade classroom in Florida, after he was first told  America is under attack on September 11, 2001?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 5 Minutes

questions.question: The CIA knew Al Qaeda operatives met secretly in Malaysia in January 2001, and that later two of them, eventual 9/11 hijackers, entered the U.S. When did the CIA share this with the FBI?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: August, 2001

questions.question: Where did an FBI investigator argue futilely with his bosses a month before 9/11, by saying: Im trying to keep someone from taking a plane and crashing into the World Trade Center.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Minneapolis

questions.question: Lawrence Wright, author of The Looming Tower, a new account of Al Qaedas attack on the U.S., reveals that the Afghans fighting alongside bin Laden in the 1980s considered him what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: useless

questions.question: U.S. military air defence jets scrambled into action as soon as news arrived that the first hijacked Boeing 727 had hit one of the twin World Trade Center towers on 9/11.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What does the Arabic term Al Qaeda mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the base, or foundation

questions.question: When America grew more entrenched in Vietnam and struggled with racial and economic problems at home, many voters and politicians alike believed the space program should be abandoned altogether.  Some of Richard Nixons closest advisors however, convinced him that the shuttle should be built.  They gave this as an example of how a reusable space vehicle would be used, and Nixon liked it.

options.text: The Shuttle would launch nuclear missiles from space
The Shuttle would captire Soviet satellites
The Shuttle would spy on enemies
The Shuttle would help build a space station

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Shuttle would captire Soviet satellites

questions.question: In the morning of September 17, 1976 the Shuttle manufacturer treated the world to a glimpse of the future; a test model of the orbiter, one not intended for space flight, rolled out of their Palmdale, CA plant.  What name had the designers given this model?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Enterprise

questions.question: What was the flight number of the hijacked plane that crashed in rural Pennsylvania on September 11, 2001?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: United 93
